texts.definition: The number of chances players has before game instances are terminated.
markups: <style="Definition">The number of chances players has before game instances are terminated.</style>

Many games include dangers that can "kill" the game elements controlled by players. <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> is a design feature in games where such a "death" does not automatically result in their game sessions ending and instead players are allowed to play until one has run out of these <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style>.

The original arcade version of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pac-Man">Pac-Man</link></style> gave players a single extra life at 10,000 points but other implementations give this at numerous occasions. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asteroids">Asteroids</link></style>, the player initially has three <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> which are lost either when the player's ship is shot by a UFO or when the ship collides with an asteroid. When all <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> have been lost, the game session ends.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike">Counter-Strike</link></style> can be regarded as a multiplayer <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooter</link></style> that makes explicit use of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style>. Here, players' avatars do not respawn when killed, instead forcing players to observe the rest of a match as spectators. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style> allow players to spawn again as long as their teams have "tickets" left, making teams share the amount of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> available (although these amount also decreases if enemy teams have control over goal locations).

Platform games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Legend%20of%20Zelda%20series">The Legend of Zelda series</link></style> can be said to be weak examples of games making use of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style>. This since the only consequence of losing all <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> is that players have to restart from the latest saved location.

The loss of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> is a <style="Link"><link="life-penalties">Life Penalty</link></style> that can have additional effects since losing all <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> can end game sessions. In addition, what caused the lose of individual <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> also can trigger other <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style> so games using <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> can consider the use of that pattern as well.

The prime characteristic of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> is that they can be lost, so deciding how this can happen is the primary design consideration when using the pattern. However, what the consequences of losing <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> are, and how many <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> are available is also important. <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> are typically associated with <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, but games using <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> or even <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style> can use <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> through the use of <style="Link"><link="parallel-lives">Parallel Lives</link></style>. They are typically not used together with <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> but are sometimes used together with <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style>. Games with <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> do quite often link the <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> of <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> with the entered <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style>; <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> are lost if the <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> are destroyed.

Losses of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> are typically the effects of failing to <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> attacks by <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> or other players in <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>, being the target of deadly <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> (possible after failing to <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> them), colliding with object due to failing with <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style>, or failing to replenish <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> within <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>. Typically, only one <style="CurrentLink">Life</style> is at stake at a time, but games using <style="Link"><link="parallel-lives">Parallel Lives</link></style> are an exception. The loss of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> can be instantaneous when one is affected or can be the effect of cumulative <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> to a <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style> value; the former being a way <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> can directly cause <style="Link"><link="life-penalties">Life Penalties</link></style> while the latter being the consequence of <style="Link"><link="energy-penalties">Energy Penalties</link></style>.

The number of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> players have are <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> and these are either <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resources</link></style> that can only be lost as gameplay progresses or <style="Link"><link="renewable-resources">Renewable Resources</link></style> that can be regained through various means (some <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Puzzle%20Games">Puzzle Games</link></style> have <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> as <style="Link"><link="regenerating-resources">Regenerating Resources</link></style>). Some game modes in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style> allow players to spawn again as long as their teams have "tickets" left, making the numbers of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> a <style="Link"><link="shared-resources">Shared Resource</link></style>. Examples of ways <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> are replenished include reaching certain <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style> (found for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asteroids">Asteroids</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pac-Man">Pac-Man</link></style>) and collecting <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style> but as <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> they can be part of most types of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>. They can also be provided through <style="Link"><link="pay-play">Pay to Play</link></style> (as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Arcade%20Games">Arcade Games</link></style> and physical <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Pinball%20Games">Pinball Games</link></style> are examples of).

<style="Link"><link="last-man-standing">Last Man Standing</link></style> goals in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> are closely related to the use of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style>.

The amount of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> available are typically presented continuously through <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="hud-interfaces">HUD Interfaces</link></style>, since they are typically a central aspect of how well gameplay in evolving in game sessions.

<style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> are almost always part of <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> are a form of (<style="Link"><link="non-localized-resources">Non-Localized</link></style>) <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> that allow players to have <style="Link"><link="extra-chances">Extra Chances</link></style> and be able to participate in games as long as players have at least one life left. This means that games with <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> must also make use of <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="game-over">Game Over</link></style> since otherwise the loss of the last <style="CurrentLink">Life</style> would not differ from any other loss of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style>. While other <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> may be attached to losing <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style>, the loss itself may be a <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style> since it reduces the number of chance left and the probable gameplay time players have left. The presence of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> give players clear <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style>: to <style="Link"><link="survive">Survive</link></style> as long as possible with each life in a game environment that may include <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>, and other players trying to succeed with <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> - it also modulates <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style> since it gives definite advantages of removing all of a player's <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style>.

As <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> are typically linked to <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, they are a way to link players' successes and failures in the game to those of their <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>. If players have developed emotional links to them, the risk of losing <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> is thereby a way of increasing their <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style>. Regardless of this, the presence of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> can increase <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>, as players have something easy to relate to that can be lost in the game. For all cases except <style="Link"><link="parallel-lives">Parallel Lives</link></style>, the use of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> implies that <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style> will be present in a game design (even if this would be that a dead <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatar</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> would rise in exactly the same place it died).

The use of the pattern implies that players have at least more than one <style="CurrentLink">Life</style>. This makes the pattern incompatible with <style="Link"><link="permadeath">Permadeath</link></style>. As multiple <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> do not exist in reality, the use of them in games can break <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>, not only by players having several lives but also through the process of <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> can also suffer from the use of <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> since these are so important to gameplay that they are typically always displayed in players' interfaces. When used with <style="Link"><link="regenerating-resources">Regenerating Resources</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Lives</style> create a form of <style="Link"><link="tick-based-games">Tick-Based Game</link></style>.
